bestBHT.bht: The salt mentioned here symbolizes the life-retaining antiseptic influence of the Spirit of God. It is good for disciples to have this salt working in them, preserving their spiritual life. However, if this salt becomes corrupted or loses its savor, the disciple becomes useless and is cast out. This passage emphasizes the need for self-renunciation and the conservation of spiritual life, serving as a warning against the loss of this vital influence within the disciple.

Henry Alford: The salt, in Scripture symbolism, is the whole life-retaining antiseptic influence of the Spirit of God."
This, working in the being My disciple, is good: but if even this be corrupted—if the mere appearance of this, and not the veritable salt (which is the savour), be in you—wherewith, &c.?
Such a disciple is to be cast out.
Marvin Vincent: Have lost its savor. See on Matthew 5:34.
Shall it be seasoned. See on Mark 9:50.
Philip Schaff: It is good then to be my disciple, in the way of self-renunciation, and thus to be the means of conserving spiritual life among men, just as salt does in the natural world." (Luke 14:34)
But if even the salt, which is very unnatural and unlikely, have lost its savor, if my disciples through a return to selfishness lose this peculiarity, where-with shall it be seasoned?" (Luke 14:34)
Our Lord is warning from a human point of view, and not giving prominence to His own Almighty sustaining power." (Luke 14:34)
John Wesley: Salt — Every Christian, but more eminently every minister. Matthew 5:13; Mark 9:50.

bhtAttempts.bht: The salt in Luke 14:34 represents the life-retaining and antiseptic influence of the Spirit of God within a disciple. It is good for a disciple to have this salt, working in them and preserving their spiritual life. However, if even this salt is corrupted or lost, the disciple is like salt that has lost its savor and is no longer useful. Such a disciple is to be cast out. The significance of this warning is emphasized as it highlights the importance of self-renunciation and the conservation of spiritual life.

The salt mentioned in this passage symbolizes the life-retaining influence of the Spirit of God. It is good for disciples to have this salt, which preserves their spiritual life. However, if this salt loses its effectiveness and is corrupted, the disciple becomes useless. As a result, the disciple is cast out. This passage emphasizes the importance of self-renunciation and the conservation of spiritual life, warning against the loss of this vital influence in the disciple's life.

The salt mentioned in Luke 14:34 represents the life-retaining antiseptic influence of the Spirit of God. It is good for disciples to have this salt working in them, preserving their spiritual life. However, if this salt loses its savor, the disciple becomes useless and is cast out. This verse highlights the importance of self-renunciation and the conservation of spiritual life, warning against the corruption of this vital influence within the disciple.

The salt mentioned here symbolizes the life-retaining antiseptic influence of the Spirit of God. It is good for disciples to have this salt working in them, preserving their spiritual life. However, if this salt becomes corrupted or loses its savor, the disciple becomes useless and is cast out. This passage emphasizes the need for self-renunciation and the conservation of spiritual life, serving as a warning against the loss of this vital influence within the disciple.

The salt referred to in Luke 14:34 represents the life-retaining antiseptic influence of the Spirit of God. It is good for disciples to possess this salt, as it preserves their spiritual life. However, if this salt loses its savor, the disciple becomes useless and is cast out. This verse underscores the importance of self-renunciation and the preservation of spiritual life, cautioning against the corruption of this critical influence within the disciple.
